lgcpspatial.loaddata module

Routines for loading and preparing Krupic lab datasets

Resolution for the camera used to record R1 is 350px/m; resolution for other rats (R11 and R18) was 338px/m Fs = 50.0 # Sample rate of data (samples/second)

lgcpspatial.loaddata.patch_position_data(px, py, delta_threshold=0.01)[source]

Linearly interpolate across noise/glitches in the position tracking.

Parameters

px (np.float32) –

lgcpspatial.loaddata.bin_spikes(px, py, s, L, w=None)[source]

Bin spikes, using linear interpolation to distribute point mass to four nearest pixels, weighted by distance.

Parameters

  • px (np.flaot32) – x location of points

  • py (np.float32) – y location of points

  • s (np.array) – spike count at each point

  • L (int) – number of spatial bins for the LxL grid

  • w (np.float32) – weights to apply to each point (default is None for no weigting)

class lgcpspatial.loaddata.Arena(px, py, L, resolution=1, radius=1.5, thr=0.1)[source]

Bases: object

Object describing the area visited by an animal within an experiment.

mask

L x L boolean matrices of grid locations within the experimetnal arena

Type

np.bool

nanmask

L x L float32 array with 1 for in-bounds points and NaN for out-of-bounds points. Multiple array data by this mask before sending to imshow() to render out-of-bounds points as transparent.

Type

np.float32

perimeter

NPOINTS x 2 list of points in the convex hull of the experimental arena in [0,1]² normalied coordinates

Type

np.float32

hull

Convex Hull object describing the arena perimeter

Type

scipy.spatial._qhull.ConvexHull

Detect peaks within distance radius of the Arena boundary.

  • radius (float) – Distance from edge to trim in pixels

Returns

is_close – Boolean array indicating

Return type

Length NPOINTS 1D np.bool

remove_near_boundary(peaks, radius)[source]

Delete peaks that are too close to the edgs of an experimental arena

Parameters

  • peaks (2 × NPOINTS np.float32) – (x,y) positions of peaks to trim in normalized [0,1]² coordinates.

  • radius (float) – Distance from edge to trim in pixels

Returns

peaks – (x,y) positions of peaks further than radius pixels from the boundary.

class lgcpspatial.loaddata.Dataset(x, y, spikes, margin=0.1)[source]

Bases: object

Class to load and extract experimental data from Krupic Lab data format.

spikes

Length NSAMPLES array of spike counts at each time point.

Type

np.float32

extent

(xstart,xstop,ystart,ystop) coordinates of 2D arena in meters. Pass this as the extent argument to imshow() to correctly position L x L grid in physical coordinates.

Type

tuple

scale

Scaling factor between (px,py)∈[0,1]² coordinates and meters. px/scale = position in meters

Type

float, units of 1/meters

px

Normalized x-position in [0,1]

Type

np.float32

py

Normalized y-position in [0,1]

Type

np.float32

margin

Margin padding argument passed to constructor. Fraction of empty space around binned data to avoid circular FFT wraparound. Ensure your prior kernel width is smaller than margin*L/2.

Type

float

from_file(margin=0.1)[source]

Load a dataset, rescaling the spatial locations.

We correct the head direction angles to align with the usual definitions of polar angles for (x,y) position data.

Parameters

  • dataset (str) – Which dataset file to load

  • margin (float) – Pading for circular convolution; default .1

Returns

A Dataset object prepared from the given grid-cell data file.

Return type

Dataset

prepare(L, P=None, spike_weights=None, blur_radius=2, doplot=False)[source]

Prepare dataset for further inference. This function bins spikes and position data, and heuristically estimates grid scale. It adds the following attributes to the Dataset object:

L

Size of L x L spatial grid for binned data. I’ve found that 128² grids work well and are a good compromise between speed, resolution, and numerical stability.

Type

int

arena

Object describing binned 2D experimental arena shape. See the documentation of the Arena class for more details.

Type

Arena

n

Length L² 1D array of total visits to each location. This is interpolated, so may contain non-integer values.

Type

np.float32

y

Length L² 1D array of total spikes at each location. This is interpolated, so may contain non-integer values.

Type

np.float32

P

Heuristic grid period from autocorrelogram

Type

float

prior_variance

Heuristic estimate of Gaussian Process prior kernel marginal variance. If this is bigger, the prior will be weighted less during Baysian inference. This heuristic estimate is biased; you should optimize the kernel hyperparameters using the ELBO if you want the posterior variance to be interpretable. See grid_search.py.

Type

float

bg_blur_radius

Low-frequency spatial scale below which rate variations are considered background fluctuations and removed.

Type

float

kde_blur_radius

Grid-period scale; Use this as the standard deviation of a Gaussian blur for a Kernel Density Estimator (KDE) of firing rate as a function of location.

prior_mean

L x L array of estimated background log-rate. Use this as a prior during Gaussian Process inference so that the calculated rate maps are defined in terms of grid-like structure above these background rate variations. This is calculated by Gaussian blurring the visits n and spike counts y with a kernel with standard-deviation bg_blur_radius, and taking the logarithm of their ratio.

Type

np.float32

lograte_guess

L x L array of KDE-estimated log-firing rate. This is calculated by blurring visits n and spike counts y with a Gaussian kernel with standard deviation kde_blur_radius, taking the logarithm of their ratio, and subtracting prior_mean.

Type

np.float32

Parameters

  • fn (str) – File path to load

  • L (int) – Number of bins in L x L spatial grid

  • P (int) – Grid period; If not provided we will estimate this from the autocorrelogram,

  • blur_radius (float) – Initial KDE blur radius for heuristic period estimate. Default is 2.

  • spike_weights (float32) – Array of sample weightings of the same length as Dataset.spikes to use when binning.

  • doplot (boolean) – Whether to show a summary plot; Default: True.

Returns

  • A Dataset object containing spatially-binned data,

  • Heurstic estimates of the grid scale, and initial

  • firing-rate maps estimated using a kernel density

  • estimator. See the PreparedDataset docstring for

  • more detail.

create_posthoc(n, y, prior_mean=0, lograte_guess=None)[source]

Bypass normal initialization and Dataset holding only binned positions and rate. This is only used by example 0 hyperparameter groundtruth test.ipynb

Returns

New dataset with spike histogram binned using the provided weights.
